Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will develop and disseminate an online educational resource called Understanding Ebola Virus Disease (UEVD). The objective is to provide users with an interactive learning experience that helps them acquire a basic understanding of factors that influence infection, transmission, and management of Ebola virus disease. Irrational fears about the current Ebola outbreak argue for the development of educational resources that can help people better understand the biology of viruses. The UEVD materials will include a knowledge pretest and posttest. These tests will allow the researchers to identify misconceptions users have about virus infection, and Ebola disease in particular, and enable them to assess how well the UEVD materials address these misconceptions.

The core of the UEVD resource is an interactive model of virus infection. Users can manipulate four to six variables that relate to important concepts associated with viral infection and spread. The virus interactive will focus on the susceptibility of the target population, the transmissibility of the virus, virulence factors, and disease spread. Users will be able to put the biology of the Ebola virus into perspective by comparing and contrasting it to other types of viruses such as measles and influenza. The goal of this educational resource is to help users acquire a basic understanding of virulence factors and transmissibility so that they can appreciate the risks of virus infection more objectively. Armed with such knowledge, users may be less fearful of rare infections like Ebola and more concerned with common infections like influenza, which kills tens of thousands of people annually in the United States. An informed public is also more likely to treat people coping with viral diseases with empathy and compassion.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Understanding Ebola Virus Disease (UEVD) project produced instructional materials useful to high school students, college students, as well as the general public. The product of the project is a website that can be accessed at http://ebola.bscs.org/

The aim of the website is to provide the user an interactive learning experience about Ebola infection and spread. The core of the website is a virus infection interactive. The interactive features six variables that taken together offer the user over 5,000 permutations. To scaffold the experience, the user is first given the opportunity to explore three variables that relate to Ebola virus characteristics. These variables are 1) R0 (the basic reproductive ratio) that refers to the number of additional people that can be infected by a single infected person during the infectious period, 2) the virus incubation period, and 3) the case fatality ratio. Next, the user can explore three additional factors that affect the spread of the outbreak and relate it to the medical response. These variables are 1) time to diagnosis, 2) isolation effectiveness, and 3) time to intervention effect. After values have been submitted for the variables, a graph is constructed showing the number of people affected over time. Separate lines on the graph correspond to the numbers of cumulative infected, cumulative deaths, hospitalized (infectious), and infectious. Finally, the user has an opportunity to make and test predictions by manipulating all six variables at the same time.

In addition to the virus infection interactive the UEVD resource also includes spatial data. A video map of West Africa illustrates the spread of the disease throughout Liberia, Guinea, and Sierra Leone over the course of the 2014-105 outbreak. A separate map of West Africa uses a swipe tool to enable the user to visualize the relationship between population density and the number of Ebola cases. A third map of the region shows where the international community located Ebola Treatment Units. Accompanying the interactive and maps is background information and discussion questions that relate to the content.

The UEVD resource is made available to the public at http://ebola.bscs.org/ which is a part of the website of BSCS (Biological Science Curriculum Study). Our partner in this project was Oregon Public Broadcasting. They are finalizing a contract with PBS Learning Media to disseminate the UEVD resource on their educational website. We anticipate that the UEVD resource will go online in April 2016 and remain active for two years.

Three image files are included to illustrate the look of the web resource. The images show the following:

  • the first part of the introduction from the welcome page,
  • a sample graph produced by the Ebola virus infection interactive, and
  • A map featuring a swipe tool that relates the number of Ebola cases in West Africa to the population density.

The principal discipline of this project is science education. The project included no funds for a summative evaluation. Statistics related to the dissemination of the resource are the only data we have that address the project’s impact.
